titleStmt.title: Transcription 8: A Gaelic Fragment in The Kingis Quair Manuscript (Oxford, Bodleian Library MS. Arch. Selden B.24)

availability.p: For internal use by the Faclair na Gàidhlig/DASG projects

note.p: The sole manuscript of The Kingis Quare and The Quare of Jealous, Oxford, Bodleian Library MS. Arch. Selden B.24, which was produced sometime during the reign of James IV (1488–1513; Boffey & Edwards 1997: 22) and which is also an important early witness to the works of Geoffrey Chaucer (d. 1400) and John Lydate (c. 1370–1451), contains a fragment of a Gaelic dán díreach quatrain. This has been inscribed by Domhnall Gorm, presumably a MacDonald of Sleat, and may be celebrating his relationship with a member of the Lothian-based Sinclair family, who commissioned and owned the manuscript, by lamenting his parting from the. Its fragmentary condition inhibits confident interpretation, however.

summary.p: The only Gaelic material in the manuscript is Domhnall Gorm's quatrain, now lacunose.

note.p: This single quatrain in rannaigecht beag is not only lacking in context but is also missing two syllables each from lines a and c. As a result, its interpretation is difficult. The best attempt is a text and translation by William MacKenzie, with the assistance of William Watson (MacKenzie 1939: 137). There are no other known manuscript versions of this quatrain, nor any known context from which it might have come

supportDesc.condition: Fol. 231v is badly eroded in places, leading to the loss of the first two syllables of lines a and c in the quatrain under discussion, as well as some text immediately above that may have offered context. The facsimile by Boffey et al. (1997) includes photographs taken under UV light, which unfortunately do not offer much improvement. However, the parts of the quatrain that have escaped erosion are very clear and present no problems.

layoutDesc.p: The quatrain is one of a number of notes, including several Scots verses, written in a single broad column in the centre of fol. 231v. The quatrain itself is set out one couplet to a manuscript line.

summary.p: A note in the main body of Arch. Seld. B.24 refers to James IV as king, meaning production of the manuscript must have been begun sometime after 1488 (Boffey et al. 1997: 4). The appearance of the date 1592 on fol. 231v, among the spare leaves towards the end of the manuscript, implies that it was complete by this date, although this is uncertain.
It is thought that it was produced for the Sinclair family in either Edinburgh or Roslin (Boffey et al. 1997: 11).

The manuscript was bequethed to the Bodleian Library as part of the collection of John Selden (1584–1654) (Brown 1899: 93). How it came to be in his collection is not known but the window between his collecting activities and the window in which the manuscript was composed is sufficiently narrow for there not to have been a significant intervening history.

revisionDesc.change: Initial draft of text transcribed and marked up from manuscript; draft introduction written.

note.p: The visibility of text drops to zero to the immediate left of the "a-" of "air", means that this might be the ending of a longer word (three syllables maximum) rather than the preposition air. In fact, lines ab, as now visible, are missing one of the two required perfect internal rhymes, and a word ending in "-uair" (: "buain") would supply such a rhyme. Nothing more can be said about this hypothesised word, unfortunately.

Some pen strokes are visible just above this line, before the page becomes too damaged for anything to be made out. It is possible that they are abbreviation strokes relating to this line (e.g. "na" could be "nam"). However, this doesn't produce any significantly more satisfying readings and letter forms, of which these marks could be the lower portions, can just about be made out above.
The slenderisation suggests that this is a prepositional form, hence the tentative translation "{on the} bank".
